ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Defining Agents/Fiduciaries, Principal-Agent, Contracts, Court Cases, Permissible/Forbidden
Learned about fiduciary law.
Definitely learned a lot about contract and fiduciary law. The economic content in the course was not particularly advanced.
I learned about key cases in the development of agency law and about formative thinkers- Calabresi and Melamed, Hohfeld, Coase, etc. and their contributions to law and economics.
I learned how you can use economics to evaluate law and vice versa.
This course taught me so much about the relationship between agents and their respective principals. The class was as great mix of legal principles and economic principles.
I learned about agency, the principal agent framework, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Interesting discussion of the basic models mentioned in principal-agent literature. Detailed notes were provided to help us better understand rather difficult topics. Four Problem Sets, Take-Home Midterm, Take-Home Final
Weaknesses: Lack of in-person office hours, Problem Sets were all assigned in the last few weeks of class
Interesting and relevant topic.

Legal material was very interesting and definitely unique to this class. Economic material was not particularly new or advanced. I sometimes felt that the legal and economic content were a bit too separated at times-- spending more time working on the integration of the two would have been interesting. Overall, Professor Brooks was very knowledgeable and engaging. 
Organization was a weak point of the course. Designated readings were not super clear, and problem sets were all assigned at the back end of the semester-- it would have been better to have had a more even distribution across the semester.

Strengths are that the content of the course is fascinating and a really great selection of papers are assigned as reading. Organization of the syllabus could be improved and more straightforward guidance about expectations for assignments would have been helpful.

Strengths: one-of-a-kind course, really interesting topics, especially if you're thinking about going into law.
Weaknesses: course felt kinda disorganized at times.  Unclear deadlines and grading policies.
Strengths: I was excited to attend class every session!

Strengths: Interesting course material, very unique to talk about law and economics. Nice professor.

Weaknesses: Class very disorganized
I thought the course went pretty well, I really enjoyed learning about the cases. At some points I was a little confused about what to do on the assignments though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I recommend this class with caution. This is cross-listed under the law school and it is far from how undergraduate classes are usually structured.
Yes, if interested in the intersection of economics and law.

Any student interested in law and economics broadly would definitely benefit from taking the course-- there is a lot of material to be had here. Hopefully, the course will be better organized in future iterations-- assignments were not spaced out well and mostly all given at the end of the semester.

I would recommend this course! Especially if you are an Econ major considering law school. I think its a great introduction to the ways that the logic and methods of Economics/Game Theory can help us to better understand fundamental questions about the law.
I would if they're looking for a nice senior Econ seminar that isn't too hard.  Just be warned it may feel a little disorganized at times.
Yes, I would reccomend it to any economics student.

Probably not. While the course material itself is interesting and worthwhile pursuing, the class itself is too disorganized to make an enjoyable or rewarding learning experience. We did not have a single grade in the class going into the final, and additionally it was unclear what topics we would cover each weak and the readings we needed to do since we stopped following the syllabus around week 2 or 3. The class is rather laid back and the professor is very nice, but I don't think this compensates for the disorganization.
Yes, I thought it was an interesting course and I dont think there are many that explore the intersection between economics and law specifically.
